keywords: RBT, GIS tools, ESRI ArcGIS Desktop, digital elevation models (DEM), profile metrics, interval distance, mean, standard deviation, coefficient of variation, filtering, outliers, CHaMP

abstract:
This text describes the River Bathymetry Toolbox (RBT), a set of GIS tools within ESRI's ArcGIS Desktop software used for analyzing and measuring river channels using high-resolution digital elevation models (DEMs). The DEMs can come from various sources such as airborne remote sensing like LiDAR or ground-based surveys.

The RBT calculates profile metrics at regular intervals along the length of a site, with customizable interval distances. These metric outputs include mean, standard deviation, coefficient of variation, filtered means and standard deviations for specific profile intervals, and all values along with their cumulative interval distance downstream from the top of the site.

Filtering is applied to remove any outlier values that are more than a specified number of standard deviations from the population mean (in this case, 4 standard deviations). This process aims to exclude unreliable data points and improve the accuracy of the metrics.

The importance of this method lies in its application to river studies, which requires precise analysis of channel features for effective monitoring and management. The RBT's ability to handle high-resolution DEMs, calculate various profile statistics, apply filtering, and provide detailed output reports makes it an essential tool for river engineers, scientists, and managers involved in assessing and mitigating the impacts of environmental changes on rivers.

description:
The River БайТ (RBT) is a collection of Geographic Information System (GIS) tools designed for use within ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software. These tools enable users to analyze and quantify river channels utilizing high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). The DEMs can be obtained from various sources, including airborne remote sensing, such as Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), or ground-based topographic surveys.

The RBT calculates profile metrics at regular intervals along the length of a study site. Users have the ability to customize the interval distance between each profile measurement. For instance, in the 2011 Consortium for the Study of the Riverа и Хаб (CHaMP) data, the interval distance was set to 0.5 meters.

Each profile metric consists of several output values:
- Mean: The average value of all profile measurements
- Standard deviation: The measure of dispersion or variability across all profile values
- Coefficient of variation (CV): The ratio of standard deviation to the mean, indicating the degree of spread in a set of data relative to its mean
- Filtered mean: The mean for a subset of selected profile intervals
- Filtered standard deviation: The standard deviation for the selected profile intervals
- Filtered coefficient of variation: The CV for the chosen profile intervals
- All profile values, along with their corresponding cumulative interval distances downstream from the top of the site

The filtered metrics report the same statistical measures but are based on a subset of the profile intervals. Filtering is implemented to exclude any data points that fall more than a predefined number of standard deviations from the population mean. In the case of CHaMP 2011, this filtering threshold was set at four standard deviations. This process aims to eliminate outliers and ensure more accurate representation of the analyzed data.

For further information on the methods used for collecting topographic measurement data that are subjected to these calculations, refer to the CHaMP - Topographic Point Collection Methods document available at http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836.
